title: Associated Items
summary: FLS Chapter 10 defines associated items as items that appear within implementations or traits. There are three kinds: associated constants, associated functions (including methods with self parameter), and associated types. iceoryx2 extensively uses all three, with particular emphasis on trait-based abstraction for IPC backends, Generic Associated Types (GATs) for reactor/guard patterns, and methods for the primary API.

10:1.rule: An associated item is an item that appears within an implementation or a trait.
10:1.notes: 1,353 impl blocks contain associated items (constants, functions, types). 88 traits define associated items.

samples.code:
impl HeapAllocator {
    pub const fn new() -> HeapAllocator {

10:2.rule: An associated constant is a constant that appears as an associated item.

10:3.rule: An associated function is a function that appears as an associated item.
10:3.notes: All functions in impl blocks are associated functions. Includes both methods (with self) and non-methods.

10:4.rule: An associated type is a type alias that appears as an associated item.

10:5.rule: An associated type shall not be used in the path expression of a struct expression.
10:5.notes: No violations found. Associated types used for type constraints, not struct construction.

10:6.rule: An associated type with a TypeBoundList shall appear only as an associated trait type.

10:7.rule: A generic associated type is an associated type with generic parameters.

10:8_to_10:11.rule: A lifetime parameter of a GAT requires a bound of form T: 'lifetime when the GAT is used in an associated function of the same trait.

samples.notes: GAT with Self: 'reactor bound for proper lifetime relationship

samples.code:
type LockGuard<'parent>: LockGuard<'parent, T>
    where
        Self: 'parent,

10:12.rule: An associated implementation constant is an associated constant that appears within an implementation.

samples.code:
impl crate::event::Listener for Listener {
    const IS_FILE_DESCRIPTOR_BASED: bool = true;

10:13.rule: An associated implementation constant shall have a constant initializer.
10:13.notes: All associated constants in impl blocks have initializers (= value).

10:14.rule: An associated implementation function is an associated function that appears within an implementation.
10:14.notes: All functions in impl blocks are associated implementation functions.

10:15.rule: An associated implementation function shall have a function body.
10:15.notes: All functions in impl blocks have bodies. Only trait declarations can omit bodies.

10:16.rule: An associated implementation type is an associated type that appears within an implementation.

10:17.rule: An associated implementation type shall have an initialization type.
10:17.notes: All associated types in impl blocks have initialization types (type X = ConcreteType).

10:18.rule: An associated trait item is an associated item that appears within a trait.
10:18.notes: 88 trait definitions contain associated items (types, constants, functions).

10:19.rule: An associated trait implementation item is an associated item that appears within a trait implementation.
10:19.notes: 773 trait implementations provide concrete associated items.

10:20.rule: An associated trait constant is an associated constant that appears within a trait.

10:21.rule: An associated trait function is an associated function that appears within a trait.

10:22.rule: An associated trait function shall not be subject to keyword const.
10:22.notes: No const fn declarations found in trait definitions. const fn not allowed in traits.

10:23.rule: Every occurrence of an impl trait type in the return type of an associated trait function is equivalent to referring to a new anonymous associated trait type.
10:23.notes: No impl Trait return types found in trait functions. iceoryx2 uses explicit associated types.

10:24.rule: An associated trait type is an associated type that appears within a trait.

10:25.rule: An associated trait type shall not have an initialization type.
10:25.notes: Trait associated types declare constraints (bounds), implementations provide concrete types.

10:26.rule: An associated trait type has an implicit core::marker::Sized bound.
10:26.notes: All trait associated types are implicitly Sized unless ?Sized is specified.

10:27_10:28.rule: An associated trait type with bounds is equivalent to a where clause.
10:27_10:28.notes: type Service: crate::service::Service is equivalent to where Self::Service: crate::service::Service

10:29.rule: An associated trait implementation function is an associated function that appears within a trait implementation.

samples.code:
impl BaseAllocator for OneChunkAllocator {
    fn allocate(&self, layout: Layout) -> Result<NonNull<[u8]>, AllocationError> {

10:30.rule: Every occurrence of an impl trait type in the return type of an associated trait implementation function is equivalent to referring to the corresponding associated trait type.
10:30.notes: No impl Trait return types in trait implementation functions.

10:31.rule: A method is an associated function with a self parameter.

10:32_to_10:36.rule: The type of a self parameter shall be one of: implementing type, &T, &mut T, or Pin<T>.

pin_self.notes: No Pin<&Self> or Pin<&mut Self> self parameters found. iceoryx2 doesn't use async patterns.

10:37.rule: The visibility modifier of an associated trait item or associated trait implementation item is rejected, but may still be consumed by macros.
10:37.notes: No visibility modifiers on trait item declarations. All trait methods implicitly have trait's visibility.

samples.name: Service
samples.notes: Core service abstraction with 11 associated types for backend configuration

generic_associated_types_gat.description: GATs provide generic parameters on associated types, enabling patterns like lending iterators and guards with lifetimes tied to parent

samples.usage: Guard type with lifetimes tied to reactor and attachment, ensuring attachment doesn't outlive reactor

samples.code:
type LockGuard<'parent>: LockGuard<'parent, T>
    where
        Self: 'parent,
samples.usage: Lock guard with lifetime tied to lock parent

impl HeapAllocator {
    pub const fn new() -> HeapAllocator {

trait_implementations.description: impl Trait for Type blocks - implementing trait contracts

trait_abstraction_for_backends.description: Traits define contracts, implementations provide platform-specific backends

gat_for_lifetime_safety.description: GATs ensure guards don't outlive their parents

builder_pattern.description: Many types have Builder associated types for configuration
